issue.title: Routing specs undefined method 'message' on Ruby 2.2
issue.body:
When upgrading from Ruby 2.1.5 to Ruby 2.2 I see test failures in all our routing specs.

```
Failure/Error: expect(get("/time_sheets")).to route_to("time_sheet/time_sheets#day")
     NoMethodError:
       undefined method `message' for #<#<Class:0x007fa9ab213160>:0x007fa998fe2948>
```

This is using rspec-rails 3.1.0 and **Rails 4.0.12**. I tried testing against rspec-rails master but it appears to be a bit convoluted.

```
Could not find gem 'rspec-core (= 3.2.0.pre) ruby', which is required by gem 'rspec-rails (>= 0) ruby', in any of the
sources.
```

I see you are already testing against Ruby 2.2 and Travis CI is passing. Curious.

body: @nathany this is fixed in rspec-rails. See rspec/rspec-rails#1261 :heart:
@cupakromer I don't understand how it would've been fixed 20 hours ago if I ran into it just an hour ago?
Could you provide more details on how to reproduce?
I'm trying to build a minimal test app. So far the issue seems to go away if I get rid of capybara. Still not totally sure.
@nathany I would expect that. `feature` is not an RSpec method. However, I do not expect the error to appear if you are running against the `master` branches.
Which capybara version are you using?
latest, 2.4.4. But I haven't been able to reproduce the issue with a minimal Ruby or Rails app yet.

This is happening in both Ruby 2.1.5 and 2.2.0 so that's unlikely to be the factor.
I'm using Rails 4.0.12, but haven't been able to reproduce the issue with a minimal test app using that version.

Ok I've reproduced. Thanks for catching this :heart:

The fix should be simple enough.

I just created a test app. Do you still need it?

Moving from the default rails_helper/spec_helper setup to ours caused the issue.

The issue is actually caused by the linked rspec-rails issue (not fixed by :grimacing:). The root of the issue is in rspec-core in how it manages multiple aliases with the same name.

The default setup does not cause the issue b/c the `spec/rails_helper.rb` loads `spec/spec_helper.rb` first. Since you were testing with `config.expose_dsl_globally = false` set in `spec/spec_helper.rb` it's turned off before either the capybara or rspec-rails aliases are registered. To the `undef_method` call is never made with `feature`.

In your sample app, you load both the Rails environment (which loads capybara) and rspec-rails while the DSL is still globally exposed; RSpec 3 still defaults to it exposed. This registers the `:feature` alias twice. When you then turn off the global DSL we attempt to undefine `:feature` twice causing the issue.

I have a fix ready to push up once I wrap up a spec for it.

Thanks for the explanation. At some point I should switch our app to separate spec and rails helpers.

Let me know when you have a fix and I'll test it out.

issue.title: Create only one example group alias per name.
issue.body:
It's possible to register the same alias multiple times. The last alias
defined, including it's metadata, will be used. This prevents the
aliases from being defined multiple times on `RSpec` and the other main
objects.

This also prevents a `NameError` when the second duplicate alias is
undefined when the DSL is no longer globally exposed.

Fix #1824

body:
Thanks @cupakromer. It's all working here.

Now just awaiting the next rspec release before adopting Ruby 2.2 (but not in a hurry).
